results.title: Gary Foley on the set of Dogs in Space in Melbourne
results.brief_description: The 1980s saw Indigenous activism and Black Power gain prominence in mainstream screen and pop culture, with activist Gary Foley appearing in the cult classic Dogs in Space (1986), which arguably reached a much wider audience than protests.
results.title_for_label: Gary Foley on the set of Dogs in Space in Melbourne
results.description: The 1980s saw Indigenous activism and Black Power gain prominence in mainstream screen and pop culture, with activist Gary Foley appearing in the cult classic Dogs in Space (1986) and the family favourite TV show A Country Practice (1989). These pop culture moments, although brief, arguably reached a much wider audience than protests and demonstrate the power of screen culture as a tool of activism, social change and the ongoing struggle for Indigenous Rights.
description_for_label: The 1980s saw Indigenous activism and Black Power gain prominence in mainstream screen and pop culture, with activist Gary Foley appearing in the cult classic Dogs in Space (1986) and the family favourite TV show A Country Practice (1989). These pop culture moments, although brief, arguably reached a much wider audience than protests and demonstrate the power of screen culture as a tool of activism, social change and the ongoing struggle for Indigenous Rights.

results.title: Bruce McGuinness in Melbourne
results.brief_description: In the late 1960s and early 70s, the Black Power movement emerged from cities and suburbs around Australia. Activist, Koori leader and filmmaker Bruce McGuinness helped strengthen the intersection of activism and filmmaking with his politically charged Black Fire (1972).
results.description: In the late 1960s and early 70s, the Black Power movement emerged from cities and suburbs around Australia. It was “the most exciting and dynamic era in modern Indigenous history” according to historian and Aboriginal activist Professor Gary Foley, who gained widespread attention for protests during the period. Fellow activist, Koori leader and filmmaker Bruce McGuinness helped strengthen the intersection of activism and filmmaking with his politically charged Black Fire (1972).
description_for_label: In the late 1960s and early 70s, the Black Power movement emerged from cities and suburbs around Australia. It was “the most exciting and dynamic era in modern Indigenous history” according to historian and Aboriginal activist Professor Gary Foley, who gained widespread attention for protests during the period. Fellow activist, Koori leader and filmmaker Bruce McGuinness helped strengthen the intersection of activism and filmmaking with his politically charged Black Fire (1972).

results.title: Wentworth Correctional Centre ID Pass for Jake Stewart
results.brief_description: Wentworth’s impact on the local industry is just as important as its global popularity, providing countless opportunities for women on both sides of the camera. It also explores complex female-focused themes including institutionalised power, female transgression and violence, motherhood and LGBTQIA+ sexuality.
results.title_for_label: Wentworth Correctional Centre ID Pass for Jake Stewart
results.description: Prop staff pass for Jake Stewart from the set of Wentworth TV series.
description_for_label: Prop staff pass for Jake Stewart from the set of Wentworth TV series.

results.title: Gulpilil: one red blood
results.creator_credit: Darlene Johnson, David Gulpilil, Tom Zubrycki and Jotz Productions
results.brief_description: David Gulpilil is one of the most respected Australian actors of his generation. Born in 1953, he grew up on an Aboriginal reserve and worked as a stockman. Possessing exceptional talents as a dancer, at age 14 he was chosen to play the lead in Nicholas Roeg’s film ‘Walkabout’ (1970). He went on to act in a number of Australian feature films including ‘Mad Dog Morgan’ (1976), ‘Storm Boy’ (1977), ‘The Last Wave’ (1977), ‘Crocodile Dundee’ (1986) and ‘Rabbit-Proof Fence’ (2002). Most recently he won the AFI award for best actor for his performance in ‘The Tracker’ (2002). When he is not acting, Gulpilil lives a demanding traditional life in Arnhem Land, Northern Australia where he is an elder of the Yolngu clan. Following Gulpilil from the set of ‘The Tracker’ back to his community the film reveals how the actor negotiates the two very different worlds he moves between. Interviews with Phillip Noyce, Rolf De Heer, Marcia Langton, Gary Foley, Jack Thompson, and others, as well as with Gulpilil, are interspersed with clips from films in which the actor has appeared.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Darlene Johnson, David Gulpilil, Tom Zubrycki and Jotz Productions

He went on to act in a number of Australian feature films including ‘Mad Dog Morgan’ (1976), ‘Storm Boy’ (1977), ‘The Last Wave’ (1977), ‘Crocodile Dundee’ (1986) and ‘Rabbit-Proof Fence’ (2002). Possessing exceptional talents as a dancer, at age 14 he was chosen to play the lead in Nicholas Roeg’s film ‘Walkabout’ (1970). He went on to act in a number of Australian feature films including ‘Mad Dog Morgan’ (1976), ‘Storm Boy’ (1977), ‘The Last Wave’ (1977), ‘Crocodile Dundee’ (1986) and ‘Rabbit-Proof Fence’ (2002). Most recently he won the AFI award for best actor for his performance in ‘The Tracker’ (2002). results.title: RMIT AIM Collection 1993
results.brief_description:
Compilation of student work from the University of RMIT Animation and Interactive Media (AIM) Department. 1993.
The Centre for Animation and Interactive Media, its courses, facilities, staff and collection of work was transferred from Swinburne University of Technology to RMIT University in 1995.
